channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Claims of Atrocities Mount as Russia Prepares a Renewed Offensive
item.description: As Ukrainian officials warn of a major Russian assault in the east, President Zelensky vowed: “We will respond.” Austria’s chancellor was meeting with President Putin in Moscow, making him the first European leader to do so since the war.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: China’s Echoes of Russia’s Alternate Reality Intensify Around the World
item.description: China’s officials and state media are increasingly parroting Russian propaganda organs on the war in Ukraine, undercutting U.S. and European diplomatic efforts, even after the killings in Bucha.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur, Steven Lee Myers and John Liu
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China, left, with President Vladimir Putin of Russia in Beijing in 2018. The countries’ many state media organs have signed dozens of pledges to share material.

item.title: Shehbaz Sharif Becomes Interim Prime Minister of Pakistan
item.description: Mr. Sharif, whose family has been dogged by accusations of graft for decades, was selected by Pakistan’s Parliament at a time of deep political divisions and economic tumult.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood and Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Saiyna Bashir for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shehbaz Sharif speaking to news media in Pakistan’s capital, Islamabad, last week after the Supreme Court announced its decision to restore Parliament.

item.title: Macron to Face Le Pen for President as French Gravitate Toward Extremes
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron and the hard-right leader Marine Le Pen will compete for a second time in a runoff on April 24.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron speaking in Paris on Sunday.

item.title: With Threats All Around, Japan Moves to Shed Its Pacifist Constraints
item.description: Growing calls for more military spending after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine demonstrate Japan’s recognition that it must bolster its own deterrent power, not just rely on its U.S. alliance.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:description: Japanese Self-Defense Forces during a joint military exercise with U.S. Marines in Gotemba, Japan, last month.

item.title: In Imran Khan’s Ouster, a Reminder of Pakistani Military’s Power
item.description: After Imran Khan’s ouster as prime minister, the legacy of his time in office is a continued military dominance of public affairs and deep polarization that could turn violent.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
item.media:description: The streets of Islamabad, Pakistan’s capital, were filled on Sunday night with thousands of supporters of Imran Khan after he was pushed out of the prime minister’s office by a no-confidence vote.

item.title: ‘Cheap as Chips’ No Longer True in U.K. as Prices Soar for a Favorite Meal
item.description: The costs for fish and chips, a working-class staple in Britain for well over a century, have rocketed as the war in Ukraine has made the main ingredients scarcer. Of 10,000 shops, 3,000 may close.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Customers at the Seabreeze fish-and-chips shop in Redcar, England.

item.title: Facing Disastrous Floods, They Turned to Mangrove Trees for Protection
item.description: In the Sundarbans, an ecological treasure straddling India and Bangladesh that is now on the front lines of climate change, local women are leading an effort to mitigate the dangers of rising waters.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj and Saumya Khandelwal
item.media:description: Members of an environmental protection group returning from their weekly survey of a nearby mangrove forest in Lakshmipur, India, in March.

item.title: A Popular British Politician Falls From Grace Over a Tax Scandal
item.description: Rishi Sunak was once considered a potential successor to Prime Minister Boris Johnson. Now he faces scrutiny over his wealthy wife’s tax status, and over holding an American green card while in office.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak last month in London. Mr. Sunak, normally a poised politician, has been thrown off balance by scrutiny over recent scandals.

item.title: Israel’s Ukraine Policy Prompts Scrutiny of Russian-Israeli Oligarchs
item.description: Israel has expressed solidarity with Ukraine but avoided direct criticism of Russia, raising questions about Russian-Israeli businessmen close to the Kremlin.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky’s speech to the Israeli Parliament was broadcast last month in a square in Tel Aviv.

item.title: War’s Disruption to Ukraine’s Farms Seeds Global Food Crisis
item.description: The Russian invasion is pummeling Ukraine’s agriculture, threatening harvests in Europe’s breadbasket and contributing to a global food crisis.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola, Valeriya Safronova and Maria Varenikova

item.title: Ukraine’s Draft Dodgers Face Guilt, Shame and Reproach
item.description: Thousands of Ukrainian men are avoiding military service, putting them on risky paths into Europe. Among Ukrainians, it’s stirring a complicated debate.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Cristian Movila for The New York Times
item.media:description: A patrol last week at the border between Moldova and Ukraine near Palanca. For many Ukrainian men fleeing the war, Moldova has become the favorite route.

item.title: In a Village Divided, Palestinians See Their Hold on Territory Eroding
item.description: Carved up over decades, the village of Walaja sits partly in the occupied West Bank and partly in Jerusalem. Palestinians say this type of fragmentation undermines prospects for a state.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: A separation wall built by Israel cutting through the Palestinian village of Walaja.

item.title: These Photographers Chase Bioluminescence in New Zealand
item.description: Capturing bioluminescence, a phenomenon in which glowing algae give crashing waves an electric blue glow, requires technical skill and a bit of luck.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:description: Alistair Bain observing bioluminescence while taking a long-exposure photograph at Te Arai Beach, Wellsford, New Zealand, in May 2020.

item.title: Russia’s Reset
item.description: A violent weekend in Ukraine shows how Russia’s goals are shifting.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
item.media:description: Destriction after Russian bombings in Kramatorsk.

item.title: This Psychiatric Hospital Used to Chain Patients. Now It Treats Them.
item.description: Sierra Leone, one of the world’s poorest countries, is working to build a modern mental health system from scratch.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Elizabeth Allieu, right, consulted with a patient, Thomas Pessimar, and his mother, Isatou Mary Pessimar, in the children’s ward of the Sierra Leone Psychiatric Hospital in Freetown.

item.title: Trump and Ukraine: Former Advisers Revisit What Happened
item.description: Amid the current crisis, Fiona Hill and other former advisers are connecting President Trump’s pressure campaign on Ukraine to Jan. 6. And they’re ready to talk.
item.dc:creator: Robert Draper
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Trent Davis Bailey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fiona Hill

item.title: U.S. Weighs Shift to Support Hague Court as It Investigates Russian Atrocities
item.description: The government is hamstrung from helping the world’s war-crimes court by two laws and a policy aimed at barring it from charging Americans.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destruction on Tuesday, in Borodianka, Ukraine, where as many as 200 people had been missing and presumed dead after intense aerial bombing.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: An exodus from eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Walking amid the rubble in Mariupol, Ukraine, yesterday.

item.title: ‘Cabaret,’ Starring Eddie Redmayne, Sweeps Olivier Awards
item.description: The musical won seven awards at Britain’s equivalent of the Tonys. A puppet-filled adaptation of “Life of Pi” and a “Back to the Future” musical also won big.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.category: Back to The Future: The Musical (Play)

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Russian Troops Mass in East Ukraine
item.description: Plus Macron and Le Pen move to the runoff for the French presidency.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: A worker cleaning up debris on Sunday outside the train station in Kramatorsk, Ukraine.

item.title: A Stricken Ukrainian City Empties, and Those Left Fear What’s Next
item.description: After the deadly strike on the train station in Kramatorsk, Ukraine, those who stayed behind are grim about the future: “We think we will be swept off the face of the earth.”
item.media:description: The parking lot of an apartment building in Kramatorsk, Ukraine, on Sunday, showing heavy damage from Russian bombings.

item.title: Volunteer Bus Drivers Help Refugees Escape from Eastern Ukraine
item.description: After a Russian strike killed more than 50 people at a train station, Ukrainians are accelerating efforts to evacuate by road.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: People waited for an evacuation bus in Kramatorsk, Ukraine, on Saturday, one day after a missile strike killed over 50 people at a train station in the city.

item.title: Why Russian Influencers Are Cutting Up Their Chanel Bags
item.description: The iconic French brand is asking customers to attest that they will not use their newly purchased items in Russia, sparking a social media protest.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Former fans of the brand have accused Chanel of discrimination for asking customers to attest that the items they were purchasing would not be taken to Russia.

item.title: Shanghai residents bristle as a lockdown enters a second week with more testing.
item.description: Residents are reaching “emotional tipping points” under the strict measures China has insisted on in handling the coronavirus, one commentator said.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: En route to get tested for the coronavirus in a residential community under quarantine in Shanghai on Saturday.

item.title: $4 a Gallon
item.description: More expensive gas could have lasting consequences.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: Pumping gas at a Shell gas station in Houston.

item.title: Macron’s pursuit of a high-tech economy stirs pre-election resentment.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman and Roger Cohen
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron visiting a technology expo in Paris last year.

item.title: An Australia Homecoming, Mixed With Yearning and Trepidation
item.description: When “Fortress Australia” sealed its borders, thousands of citizens were stuck abroad. When allowed to return home, a reporter wondered how she would find the country — and how it would find her.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Isabella Moore

item.title: Why Calls for War Crimes Justice Over Ukraine Face Long Odds
item.description: If those in power act as if they are immune to the laws of war, it may be because they often are. But following through is not necessarily an empty exercise.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A basement room in Bucha, Ukraine, in which the bodies of five people were found with their hands bound when the town was liberated last week.

item.title: The agriculture secretary is the latest addition to a coronavirus wave disrupting the Biden administration.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Kannapell and Juston Jones
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack in September. His department announced on Saturday that he had tested positive for the coronavirus and would be isolating and working remotely in the coming days.

item.title: Imran Khan Ousted as Pakistan’s Prime Minister
item.description: The country will now face early elections after days of brinkmanship in which Mr. Khan tried to dissolve Parliament to head off the no-confidence vote.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
item.media:description: Imran Khan, center, last month during National Day in Islamabad. He was ousted as Pakistan’s prime minister on Saturday, losing a no-confidence vote in Parliament.

item.title: While life expectancy is rebounding in parts of the world, white deaths drive a further U.S. drop.
item.dc:creator: Alex Lemonides
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial in September in Washington representing each of the more than 600,000 U.S. Covid deaths at the time. The toll has now surpassed 980,000.

item.title: Boris Johnson Visits Kyiv As Britain Promises Aid to Ukraine
item.description: Mr. Johnson, an enthusiastic supporter of President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, walked with him and a group of soldiers through the streets of the capital, Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Press Service, via Reuters
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain traveled to Kyiv, Ukraine, on Saturday to meet with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine.

item.title: Pandemic aid stalled in the Senate and Shanghai remained in lockdown: The week in Covid news.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Downes
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: Additional pandemic funding for testing and vaccines stalled in Congress this week.

item.title: Wave of Terrorism in Israel Defies a Simple Narrative
item.description: Four recent deadly attacks have highlighted Palestinian anger over vanishing prospects of a Palestinian state, but the assailants’ diverse backgrounds have left many questions unanswered.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: A memorial at the site of a deadly attack last week in Tel Aviv.

item.title: Russia Shuffles Command in Ukraine as Thousands Flee the East
item.description: The Russian campaign will be consolidated under a veteran of the Syrian war, while Western nations pump additional arms into Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt, Jane Arraf and Michael Levenson
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: The crowded train station in Dnipro, Ukraine, on Saturday, as people fled ahead of the expected Russian assault in the eastern part of the country.

item.title: Putin’s War in Ukraine Shatters an Illusion in Russia
item.description: Russians long lived with an understanding: Stay away from politics, and live your life as you choose. The war in Ukraine wrecked that idea.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin’s image was projected onto the side of a building during a speech last year in Moscow.

item.title: In Mariupol’s Drama Theater, a Cry for ‘Mama!’ That Offered Brief Relief
item.description: A family shares its story of surviving the Russian attack on a theater that officials in the besieged southern Ukrainian city believe killed about 300 people.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Viktoria Dubovitskaya, center, sitting with her son, Artyom, 6, as her daughter, Nastya, 2, ran around in the common area of the shelter that they were staying in last month in Lviv, Ukraine.

item.title: Latest E.U. Sanctions Get Personal With Putin’s Daughters and Confidantes.
item.description: The targets included one of the most trusted technocrats in Mr. Putin’s economic policy team and the head of a construction empire who used to practice judo with the Russian leader.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Alexey Nikolsky/Sputnik, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Herman Gref, the architect of President Vladimir V. Putin’s earlier economic reforms, with the Russian leader in Moscow in 2019.

item.title: New Rites of Spring
item.description: While we engage in the usual rituals of the changing season, we’re growing accustomed to spring cleaning our minds as well.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Women in Poland Offer Safe Transit to Ukraine’s Refugees
item.description: With women and children at high risk of exploitation, a volunteer collective called Women Take the Wheel is helping them make the journey.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Katarzyna Garbarska, a volunteer with Women Take the Wheel, drove Marina Bardash and her daughters from the Polish border with Ukraine toward the city of Katowice this month. Ms. Bardash and her daughters are refugees from Kyiv.

item.title: Canada Moves to Ban Foreign Real Estate Buyers for Two Years
item.description: Among the many budget measures to make housing more affordable is a two-year ban on sales to foreign buyers. But details are scarce.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Building homes in Ontario, which recently raised its foreign buyers tax to 20 percent.

item.title: With Macron and Le Pen Leading Election Field, a Fractured France Decides
item.description: In Dijon, magnificence and malaise sit side by side, in the image of a country divided before the presidential vote on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Campaign posters of the presidential candidates on display this week in Dijon.

item.title: Spurred by Putin, Russians Turn on One Another Over the War
item.description: Citizens are denouncing one another, illustrating how the war is feeding paranoia and polarization in Russian society.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A screen last month in St. Petersburg, Russia, showing a “Z” symbol in the colors of the St. George ribbons.

item.title: Japan Aligns With U.S. and Europe in Penalizing Russia Over Ukraine War
item.description: The country has announced a ban on Russian coal and restrictions on imports including timber, vodka and machinery. It is also expelling eight Russian diplomats.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: A police officer standing guard outside the Russian Embassy in Tokyo on Friday.

item.title: Saudi Arabia will allow a million hajj pilgrims to visit Mecca, with Covid precautions.
item.description: Vaccinations and negative tests will be required for those who attend the annual ritual.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Muslims gathering during Ramadan around the Kaaba in Mecca, Saudi Arabia, last week. The kingdom announced plans and Covid restrictions for the annual hajj on Saturday.

item.title: The BA.2 subvariant prompts a slight increase in new U.S. cases.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Downes
item.media:credit: Alisha Jucevic for The New York Times
item.media:description: Santa Monica, Calif., on Wednesday. The national average of new coronavirus cases rose for the first time in weeks on Friday.

item.title: At least 53 people have tested positive for the coronavirus after attending an A-list Washington dinner.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:description: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland was among 53 people who tested positive for the coronavirus this week after attending a dinner in Washington.

item.title: Missile Strike Kills At Least 50 at Ukraine Train Station
item.description: Ukraine’s president blamed Russia for the latest atrocity in the six-week-old war, calling the Russian invasion force “an evil that has no limits.” Moscow denied responsibility.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Michael Levenson
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Bodies were covered in tarpaulin after a missile attack on the railway station in the eastern city of Kramatorsk, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: The F.A.A. recommends a record $81,950 fine for an unruly passenger.
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Federal Aviation Administration is recommending its largest ever fines against unruly passengers, for two women who are accused of assaulting flight crew members last year.

item.title: Russian Blunders in Chernobyl: ‘They Came and Did Whatever They Wanted’
item.description: Tank treads ripped up the toxic soil, bulldozers carved trenches and bunkers, and soldiers spent a month camped in — and dug into — a radioactive forest.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Ivor Prickett
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A crushed car and other detritus littered a main intersection in the abandoned town of Chernobyl.

item.title: Boris Johnson Urges Germany Not to Let Up Pressure on Russia
item.description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson is pressing European allies to take a hard line, like cutting off Russian energy imports, but after Brexit, his influence is limited.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain and Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany outside Mr. Johnson’s residence on Friday in London.

item.title: Gerda Weissmann Klein, Honored Holocaust Survivor, Dies at 97
item.description: Her story was told in an Oscar-winning documentary, and her message of hope and love in the face of overwhelming evil was an inspiration to millions.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: The Holocaust survivor Gerda Weissmann Klein received the Presidential Medal of Freedom from President Barack Obama at the White House in 2011.

item.title: Supply Chains Tainted by Forced Labor in China, Panel Told
item.description: Human rights activists and others urged the Biden administration to cast a wide net to stop imports of products made with forced labor in Xinjiang.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A worker at a Huafu Fashion plant during a government-organized tour for foreign journalists in Xinjiang last year. U.S. sanctions are meant to combat forced labor in the region.

item.title: A ‘New Era of Air Pollution’ in the Tropics Could Have a Huge Toll
item.description: Increasingly bad air in big cities is expected to kill hundreds of thousands in coming years if stronger controls are not put in place.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Munir Uz Zaman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Melting down wires to extract metal in Dhaka, Bangladesh.

item.title: Officials Say Russian Art, Seized by Finns, Should Return Home
item.description: Finnish custom officials had seized the art several days ago, but the Finns and European Union officials decided that art lent to museums for exhibit did not come under sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Graham Bowley
item.media:description: Crates of art from Russian museums that were seized by Finnish customs officials. Officials later decided the art, which had been on loan to institutions in the West, was not subject to sanctions.

item.title: India Approves Booster Shots for Adults Between Ages 18 and 60
item.description: Experts said that one reason for the shift was that many Indians were finding it hard to travel abroad without booster certificates.
item.dc:creator: Karan Deep Singh
item.media:description: A line for a boat last month at the Gateway of India, an attraction in Mumbai, India, as pandemic travel restrictions were relaxed.

item.title: A DHL Cargo Plane Breaks in Two Landing at a Costa Rica Airport
item.description: No one on board was injured, a spokesman for the delivery company said, adding that it was working with the authorities to remove the plane.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: A cargo jet headed for Guatemala made an emergency landing at Juan Santamaria International Airport in Costa Rica.
